name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the report by Guillaume Balas, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) no.883/2004 concerning the coordination of social security systems and Regulation (EC) no.987/2009 which establishes the methods of application of Regulation (EC) no.883/2004 (COM (2016) 0815 - C8-0521 / 2016 - 2016/0397 (COD)) (A8-0386 / 2018).

name: Guillaume BALAS
text: protractor. - Mr President, in December 2016, the revision of Regulation (EC) No 883/2004 on the coordination of social security systems was proposed by the Commission. It is indeed necessary today to considerably improve the situation concerning the freedom of movement of workers in the European Union, since we are faced with the following paradox: a market allowing freedom of movement, but very different social systems, therefore fragile situations for workers in terms of rights protection and portability of rights. That was, and still is, the whole point of this review. We worked for over a year in Parliament and we have made, I believe, three major breakthroughs. The first, which is absolutely essential, is the strengthening of the applicable legislation, that is to say, knowing what is the applicable law for a mobile worker - posted workers, for example, but they are not the only ones. For this, one question is essential today: to ensure that a worker is effectively affiliated to a social security system and that he enjoys all of his rights. This is why we proposed that there be three months of prior work before being able to be sent to another country, to ensure the affiliation link between a worker and a social security system, and that of course to avoid the fraud we know is so massive. Likewise, another proposal was accepted: the prior notification by a company of the dispatch of a worker to another country. This is absolutely essential today because, as we know, a large part of the workers sent to another country are not even known in that country. Certain national laws, in particular, admit that within a certain period, there is no need for any document to go to work in another country and that no control can be done. This is, I believe, a serious attack on the dignity of workers, their security, their right to be affiliated to a social security system. This is the reason for this notification proposal. The improvement of cooperation between states was also desired by Parliament, in particular through a very original system which combines coercion on Member States by posting a deposit and freedom of movement. This provides great flexibility, especially in the ability of workers to move from one border to another. Social justice measures are also proposed, in particular through the six months of exportation of unemployment benefits, because how can we imagine that someone can work for years in a country and that when he leaves, he does not only entitled to three months of exporting unemployment benefits? Six months is better; it may not be enough, but it already is. We had obviously also imagined, for frontier workers, this freedom of affiliation to the social security system, which is a big step forward. I want to say the following, especially and mainly to the right, to the right, but not only: do not think that it is by imitating populism and nationalism that you are going to respond to populism and nationalism. It is even sometimes such a paradox that some nationalists have become wiser than you on matters of the coordination of social security systems. Stop this permanent parliamentary obstruction, let the debate take place, let us vote so that we, as Parliament, can have a strong position for the next term. So, yes, let's vote for this proposal at first reading. For the future, I would like to give the Commissioner - whom I thank for all the work she has done - my full agreement that the coordination regulation will henceforth be revised by a simple majority in the Council, in order to remove the blockages observed, in particular no later than two weeks ago. This would be a major step forward for European workers, who could finally be protected against national egoisms.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am pleased to be here for this debate on the revision of the regulations on social security coordination. Fifteen years after the last revision, this Commission has proposed a new and necessary modernisation. That modernisation is much needed to address new challenges and opportunities in the fields of long-term care, unemployment benefits, family benefits and the rules on applicable legislation for posted workers. We adopted our proposal more than two years ago in order to ensure fairness in the free movement of workers and citizens in the internal market. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Guillaume Balas, and the many Members of the Parliament who deeply invested in this file, to bring about the improvements that our citizens, our workers and our businesses are waiting for. Facilitating parental leave allowances for mobile citizens, clarifying the right of citizens in need of long-term care, giving job seekers more opportunities to find work abroad – these are some examples on how the proposed modernisation would improve citizens’ daily life. For me, honourable Members, it has always been essential to coordinate social security systems with rules that are clear, fair and enforceable. This is indeed the only way to secure continued support for our internal markets. Fairness means that the rules are equitable to all and not designed to benefit one category of stakeholders to the detriment of the others. It means taking into account the interests of both the Member States of origin and the receiving Member States. Fairness means rules that allow mobile citizens and workers to move to another country in proper conditions and take into account the interests of taxpayers and the interest in maintaining adequate social security systems. Fairness means for me also preserving the business opportunities for all the companies and the self-employed that make use of free movement in good faith to serve clients across Europe, be it businesses or consumers. And fairness also means preserving and improving tools to fight abuses and fraud. These are the principles on which we have based our proposal.  These have also been the objectives that have guided us throughout the interinstitutional negotiations with the Parliament and the Council. The provisional agreement that we reached in trilogues has not been confirmed, because there was no sufficient majority amongst the Member States. But I believe that the compromise that we reached should inspire us for the work that remains to be done.  Mr President, dear rapporteur, shadow rapporteurs, Members of Parliament, this Parliament now has the opportunity to agree on its position in first reading and thereby open the way for further progress in this important file. I count on your constructive spirit and on our shared motivation to make good use of this opportunity. This is what our citizens, our workers and our businesses expect from us.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Thank you Commissioner, and now we are listening to the opinion of the political groups and, in this first stage, we are not accepting 'blue cards'.For the Popular Party group, Hon.Schulze, one minute and thirty.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! In my view, one of the most important laws is the coordination of social security systems. That has really taken Europe a long way. In doing so, we are essentially regulating the free movement of workers, one of the basic ideas of our united Europe. In my opinion, however, too little time was given to us MEPs for this important and very extensive law. The Commission also presented the legislative proposal relatively late. It is of course difficult to get a fair result before the European elections. We had to vote in committee under great time pressure, and there was not enough time for the trialogue either - obviously too little time to find a result that the Council could also have agreed to. But there are positive things that we also achieved in the trialogue. For example, we now also have coordination rules for long-term care, we have an important exception for secondments, namely the exceptions for business trips, so that we also continue to enable short-term secondments. But there are also downsides. I don't like the idea that, according to the European Parliament, you should in future unsubscribe from every posting. The idea is actually well meant, but can probably only be implemented with modern technology and digitization. An example: If you as a teacher are planning a school trip to a neighboring country - is that already a posting or not? The committee's report also goes too far on the issue of unemployment benefits. The export services have already been mentioned, or the topic of cherry-picking, which we can get if we introduce the right to vote on the topic of cross-border commuters in the future. We did find out in the trialogue result, but the trialogue result is not up for voting here. I think we could get a better result. We need more time for this in the new parliament, after the European elections. The EPP Group will be ready to help ensure that we get a better result after the European elections.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (NL) Mr President, we have before us a comprehensive package that contains absolutely good things, but also bad points. Bottom line, however, the PVDA must vote against this proposal. We are not against the transferability of unemployment benefits, but against this effect. In the Netherlands we have seen two major cases of organized fraud involving unemployment benefits in recent years. Employees must be able to be sure that everyone contributes and that no one receives an unfair benefit, because the employees pay for it through the contributions. In this proposal, the obligation to apply for a job and being available for the labor market will in practice disappear. The extension of the transferability of unemployment benefits also contributes to an export carousel. One half year employers hire people, but the other half year the contract is not renewed and people are referred to benefits. We must first do something about this if we really want to continue to protect employees against unemployment. For us, the solidarity of the system is paramount and that is not guaranteed with this proposal.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - (NL) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, everyone agrees: social fraud must be fought very hard. For example, the social inspections of all Member States must be able to cooperate much more smoothly and better. In addition, there must be a minimum period of days worked before foreign workers can claim our unemployment benefits. It is perfectly logical that non-Belgian workers have first contributed sufficiently to Belgian social security before they are entitled to unemployment benefits. That is why I stand by the Commission proposal of at least three months of work before people can receive benefits. Six months work requirement would be even better. But the opposite is true: the left would like to limit the work requirement to one day, which is utter madness. In this way you undermine support for our social security. The left also wants to allow jobseekers to take their unemployment benefits with them when they move back to their country of origin. But this makes the control of activation completely impossible. This encourages abuse. Statistics also show that a significant number of people who return to their own country do not find work within three months. Why should they also search? With a Belgian unemployment benefit you can live very comfortably in an Eastern European country! Flanders is an export-oriented economy, but our social security is not an export product! In other words: no benefits without contributions!

name: Marian HARKIN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, as legislators, our responsibility is to ensure that whatever legislation we support tomorrow will improve the current situation, will address identified problems or blockages, will contribute to free and fair movement of workers, and will ensure trust, certainty and social fairness and a level playing field for all workers. That’s our benchmark in the Group of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe (ALDE). Therefore, in ALDE, we believe that the original Commission proposal is a decent attempt at achieving an improved regime.  The draft agreement at trilogue had a number of positive elements, but the Council could not support it. There are positive elements in today’s report on family benefits, on long—term healthcare and on the non-codification of the European Court of Justice (ECJ) judgments. However, we believe that the amendment on Article 13, which could include drivers, would cause nightmares for drivers and employers, potentially subjecting drivers to a number of different social security regimes, and we have tabled amendments to remove that proposal. We do not agree that frontier workers can choose which social security system they will benefit from. This would cause huge uncertainty for Member States and undermine the social contract between cross—border workers and national workers. We don’t support one aggregation. Again, this will, in some Member States, create an anomaly between cross—border and national workers. If our amendments on these matters are accepted, we can, on balance, support this legislation. But, if they are not accepted, we believe it will not deliver balanced and fair legislation.  Finally, can I thank the rapporteur and shadow rapporteurs for their commitment to this dossier. We didn’t always agree, but we certainly worked our best.

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! It seems to me, after listening to you, that some of my colleagues here in Parliament do not want to understand the basic principle of the coordination of social security systems. The point is that claims that have been acquired are recognized when you move to another country - nothing else. Anyone who says: You can only get entitlements if I have paid into the respective national system in which I work, is precisely misunderstanding this basic principle. We can then stop even wanting to talk about a social union. Please finally commit yourself! Stop using all kinds of tricks to prevent a debate about the position of the Employment and Social Affairs Committee in the vote. I think that's undemocratic. We can change it if the majority want it. But simply ending the debate and not wanting to have a vote in this legislature has nothing to do with parliamentary democracy. This cherry-picking is destroying the European Union. Free movement must apply to all people in the European Union. It must be socially secure for everyone. That's what we're talking about here. The majority in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs has reached a very progressive position. We put them up for debate. This can be voted on. On the left, we are voting in favor because there should be a longer export of unemployment benefits - six months. We are voting in favor because loopholes for social security fraud in posting will be closed. And we also vote in favor because care services are coordinated as an independent service. But we are particularly against the fact that some - especially conservatives and right-wing extremists - are trying to enforce child benefit indexation. Eastern European women - in Germany, for example - should receive less child benefit if their children stay at home in Poland or Romania. These people are supposed to be discriminated against - people who work hard, who have paid up, who pay for their benefits, who pay taxes and social security contributions, and who also want to visit their children at home. We will reject this indexing. Finally, on the question of social equality: we must defend social equality for all EU citizens in Parliament. Nobody should be treated as a second class EU citizen. That must apply to unemployment benefits. If someone has deposited in one country, it has to be recognized in another. And there is still a fundamental gap in the framework of the EU's free movement of people: we as the EU must ensure that citizens in all countries have the right to access social security systems.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, when I first came to this Parliament some 20 years ago now, the first legislative file I worked on was the overall revision of the coordination of social security systems. We voted through that agreement, now Regulation (EC) No 883/2004, in the final plenary week of that parliamentary term. I had hoped by the time I had finished my time in Parliament to be voting through a similar agreement with Council on the latest update, but unfortunately that’s not going to be the case due to big divisions in Council. And why not? Because I believe this file has become a mix of narrow national political interests and people trying to use the regulation to fix problems which are not its core business.  My political group has tried to keep the citizen as the person concerned in the language of the text at the centre of that approach, and those citizens are not only workers, family members, students, travellers, but anyone covered by a social security system and in a cross—border situation. We welcome the clear inclusion of long-term care in the updated regulation, but we start from the belief that the overwhelming majority of citizens and their employers want to stay on the right side of the rules and thus protect their entitlements, so it helps if the rules are clear and as easy as possible to follow, with a degree of flexibility that reflects and assists daily life. It also helps if there is an effective administration that responds quickly and assists people, rather than acting as a bureaucratic barrier that pushes people to take chances.  Generally, we support the committee report. The only amendment – Amendment 197 – that we’ve reintroduced concerns this blessed A1 form, an attestation and not a permission, and we’ve proposed the issuing of an open A1, valid for three months, so that an individual who travels often on business doesn’t have to make multiple applications that are time-consuming for the person concerned and the administration.  As regards the other amendments tabled, we don’t support the indexation of family benefits. We believe that a cross-border worker is entitled to equal treatment, and that such a measure is not cost effective, though some governments may find it politically expedient.  We also point out that this report strengthens the oversight possibilities for Member States and they can always adopt bilateral measures if necessary, which makes far more sense than trying to adapt the whole regulation to fix a bilateral problem. So we believe the committee has found a sound basis for this proposal, and we believe it provides a sound basis for negotiation for the next Parliament.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: - Mister President!No blue card is allowed, but I would like to say one point of order: you came ten minutes late, we started the debate ten minutes late, so we cannot make a blue card.If we had done that, I would have liked to ask Ms. Zimmer what she perceives as trickery here when parties exercise their normal right to submit applications.This is no trickery, Ms. Zimmer, I have to tell you very clearly.And, Mr President, if you had come on time, we would have been able to use the blue card procedure.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mr President, our group has taken a wait-and-see attitude towards this text. Indeed, if the text which allows the free movement of people is very old, it can perfectly be understood within the framework of cooperation, as we understand it, within the European alliance of nations to which we aspire. In our opinion, this text brings some improvements, in particular in terms of the security given to cross-border workers and families whose parents work in different countries. But we also obviously set up as an absolute dogma the principle according to which the country collecting the contributions must be the one which pays the benefits. However, we also have some regrets about this text. We deplore the determination of the scope of long-term illnesses, of which it should be noted that in France, they represent 70% of the social security budget, a rate which must be comparable in many European countries. We also regret the fact that, in the text presented by the rapporteur, the legal residence requirement has disappeared and that only case law matters, which itself is subject to interpretation. Finally, we regret that opposition, especially from the right, did not allow us to guarantee prior authorization. That’s why the trialogue failed. However, it is quite clear that we want this text to pass, since it is a step forward, but we urge that this text provide for a system to prevent potential fraud: it is imperative that there has prior authorization.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: - Mr Chairman! Any situation in which money is taken from some to give to others, when it is taken from those who work and distributed to those who do not work is immoral and stupid. And now those who do more of this stupidity demand solidarity in stupidity from those who do less stupidity. A glance at these meticulous regulations shows just how bureaucratic we are. If a state needs a definition of a business trip, it is a sick country. Please do not take the freedom of movement and freedom in your teeth when you are simultaneously calling for permits, inspections, reporting, limiting the time of the delegation. If, on top of that, you think your welfare rights keep people from getting around, my idea is simple: let's take your welfare benefits and be at peace. You say this is conducive to fraud. Well, who would have expected it to be fraudulent! We will abolish benefits - there will be no frauds. The last-minute throwing in of such controversial projects by the collapsing left when you already know that people are fed up with you, and when the polls show it, is a manifestation of hypocrisy, as is the simultaneous reference to democracy at this point because people do not want your more of yours. socialist experiments. Socialism is going bankrupt and we thank you.

name: David CASA
text: - On behalf of the President, the President of the European Union took an important role in the European Union and the European Union. L-emendi proposti huma estensivi u essenzjalment jindirizzaw miżuri għal min hu qiegħed, benefiċċju għal kur fit-tul, għall-posted workers: dan huwa naturalment pożittiv. For the purposes of this Regulation, the Council has adopted a report on the various aspects of the proposal. If this is not the case, the name of the company will be limited to the number of years and the name of the company will be reduced to risk. Dan ukoll minħabba nuqqas ta 'maġġoranza fil-Kunsill. Għalhekk ma nistgħux niżbaljaw. Irridu niżguraw li kwalunkwe tibdiliet li jsir fil-liġi ttejjeb il-ħajja tan-nies u ma jkunx ta 'xkiel għaċ-ittittini, għal min jaħdem, kif ukoll għal min iħaddem jew hu self-employed. If necessary, the number of these items is shown in the column. For the purposes of this Regulation, the European Union shall have the right to use the European Union. In the case of non-compliant operations, the rapporteur and the Member States may, in the case of natural disasters, use the required level of effort in order to ensure that the aid does not exceed the requirements of this Regulation.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, dear Commissioner, there is no doubt that updating the rules to facilitate labor mobility and ensure equal access to social security systems for mobile workers who continue to grow in Europe is a step. important in building a more inclusive and more social Europe and the coordination of social security systems meets this European principle of freedom of movement, although, of course, since social security systems are subject to the exclusivity of states, this is just coordination, but this coordination would have been a big step towards greater legislative clarity and harmonization. Unfortunately on some issues that we consider important, such as that relating to cross-border and transnational workers, who can decide where to receive unemployment benefits and are fragile workers who deserve protection - the other complex point under discussion is that of manner and location. where to receive unemployment benefits for job seekers in another European country - these are rules that we will unfortunately not be able to fully define. It is a pity, because I believe that on the trilogue proposals, if we had managed to reach an agreement, we would have obtained a good result. As you said, Commissioner, unfortunately, we will have to postpone until next time.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: - Sir. Chairman! The legislation that is being adopted here on social benefits in Europe is another sad milestone in Europe's persistent attack on the Danish model. It is a defense of welfare tourism, it is a defense of social dumping, and it is a step in the fundamentally wrong direction. It is not the case that these security schemes will mean equal rights for EU citizens and national citizens, in a number of cases they will mean better rights for EU citizens than for national citizens. For example, when it comes to Danish unemployment benefits: It is completely insane that you should be able to earn Danish unemployment benefits in an insurance scheme that is at a much lower level, and therefore the Danish People's Party clearly rejected that you should be able to get in any way access to national welfare benefits without having earned them on exactly the same terms as national citizens. And if we can not get through with it, then you should at least get these welfare benefits indexed so that they do not have an exorbitantly high level when you take them home to your home country, whether it is SU, unemployment benefits or the myriad of others welfare benefits to which the EU entitles EU citizens in Denmark.

name: Yana TOOM
text: – Mr President, one of the four freedoms enjoyed by EU citizens is the free movement of workers. Free movement is hardly possible without social guarantees for workers and their family members, and efficient coordination of Member States’ social security systems. When mobile workers move between EU Member States for jobs, one key concern is that they can lose social rights earned in another country. It is also clear that the number of cross-border workers could increase if there was better coordination of social security systems between neighbouring Member States. Regretfully, the current regulation is outdated and ought to be revised. Hard work was done in both my parliamentary committees, the Committees on Petitions and on Employment and Social Affairs, but as we know, our trilogue agreement was finally not possible due to the conflicting views in the Council. No doubt we’ll go back to this topic in the very near future. In this context, I would also like to underline that national discrimination against mobile workers is clearly outlawed by the Treaties. I regret any attempt to put artificial obstacles for Eastern European workers in their access to social benefits in the old Member States. Most importantly, I cannot support the indexation of family benefits in the place of residence of the children. This measure is both inappropriate and discriminatory, and it creates a complex, expensive and unnecessary bureaucratic monitoring system. Similar discriminatory measures should not be included in any future proposals regarding coordination of Europe social security systems.

name: Rina Ronja KARI
text: - Sir. Chairman! Ladies and gentlemen, today we are faced with the fundamental question: how much should the EU really interfere in the countries' unemployment benefit system? And we have to keep in mind that countries have vastly different systems. A proposal that may work well in one country can have catastrophic consequences in another country. We must protect citizens, but we must not undermine well-functioning systems. And quite frankly, the proposal on the table today risks undermining the Danish unemployment benefit system - a system that is otherwise built on solidarity between workers. A system where those at work temporarily help those who are out of work. Giving the right to unemployment benefits after just one day's work in another EU country and giving the right to take them out of the country for 6 months is simply opening the door to social dumping. It will have catastrophic consequences. So the question is now fundamental: should the EU really interfere in our unemployment benefit system? My answer is quite clear: No, the EU must intervene completely!

name: Terry REINTKE
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! The Brexit drama that we are currently witnessing in Great Britain did not start with the referendum just three years ago. For decades there was really systematic hate speech against the European Union, and especially in the last few years against EU citizens who live in Great Britain. This debate was very often based on a discussion about the indexing of child benefit - a debate of envy that does absolutely nothing to social equality in Great Britain, but only poisons the social climate and divides society. I want to be very clear: indexing child benefit would not solve a single problem of social injustice in Great Britain or in other European countries, it would only result in inequality of workers and create more bureaucracy. Therefore: if we want to live in a united and social Europe, then we must reject the indexing of child benefit. At the same time, however, we must also realize that we have to do a lot more for social justice within the European Union. Because the regions in Great Britain that are hardest hit by social inequality and poverty are also the ones that voted most in favor of Leave in the referendum. For a long time the EU has not done enough to prevent workers and citizens from being played off against each other. We have to realize that the conditions for a Brexit are in place in all member states of the European Union. Growing social inequality combined with agitation against the European Union is an absolutely explosive mixture. If we want this common European project to grow closer together, then we have to make it more social, and then we have to tackle these two challenges together. Good coordination of social security systems is an absolutely essential prerequisite for this.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: - Madam President! As the new parliament will deal with further negotiations, I would like to appeal to the new Members to be cautious and cautious. Firstly, we must guarantee equal treatment for migrant workers. People who decide to move to another Member State to work there should enter the social security system of the host country as soon as possible. It is also important for migrant workers to extend the period during which they can export acquired unemployment benefits from three to six months. Special arrangements for frontier workers are also needed. There can also be no question of introducing indexation of family benefits. In the case of posted workers, we should avoid significant changes. Companies providing services abroad are facing huge administrative burdens and new regulations resulting from the new Posting of Workers Directive. Clauses that would lead to fragmentation of social security should be avoided. The worker must be sure where he pays contributions and where he and his family are insured. It is therefore necessary to maintain a twenty-four month period during which contributions are paid in the sending country. The current wording of Art. 13 of Regulation 987/2009, which applies to people working in two or more Member States, i.e. drivers. These persons should be insured in the country of their stay. A difficult task ahead of the new European Parliament, but I believe that the new MEPs will show common sense and caution.

name: Emilian PAVEL
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank you very much for your work, for your proposal and for the way you are defending - so to speak - or combating this indexation of social benefits for raising a child. I want to thank you for the firm position that you have always held and that you maintain. I want you to tell us, perhaps at the end, how we are in Austria, what is happening with that infringement procedure, whether or not you extend this procedure. I would like to point out, however, that in this debate, some colleagues, who think they are on the left, forget that a few years ago we voted against social dumping in the European Parliament. It was then called "for equal work, equal pay." Dear colleagues, for equal work, equal social protection everywhere in Europe! Let's stop losing votes to the far right and continue to be pro-European. This program, this report is a compromise one, but it is one that takes the European Union further. It is one that must be voted on and work on it must continue.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Dear Chairman, the mobility of workers has opened an important issue of social security of workers in cross-border work. In order for them to be able to consume their rights without hindrance, the competent authorities of the Member States must cooperate better with each other and national legislation must be harmonized as much as possible. I am aware of the need to make some progress in this area, but I cannot support the proposed solution because it introduces new complications and opens up space for fraud. The social system must remain primarily the responsibility of the Member States, and mobile worker rights should be exercised in the home country until they expire or until they are waived. Until then, he should not be entitled to compensation in the Member State in which he wishes to find work. By entering the labor market in another country, the worker should lose the right to compensation in the home country or in the Member State in which he previously exercised that right. More complicated solutions, although at first glance seem more favorable to workers, will only introduce legal disorder and further burden social systems.

name: Morten LØKKEGAARD
text: - Madam President!In the Liberal Party, we are in favor of migrant workers in Europe having proper conditions.No doubt about it.But that goal is unfortunately far from being achieved with this bill.The proposal now in place creates a great deal of legal uncertainty, risks putting migrant workers better off than their colleagues in the country to which they come, and it opens up a completely unreasonable export of unemployment benefits and child benefits.The proposal we are facing here is significantly inferior to the one that we unfortunately did not get through with in an edited form.This is the Commission's first proposal.It is a piece of legislative power to put it bluntly, and I would strongly urge us to vote it down.

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: Madam President, every country in the European Union has different social security systems, different rules, budgets and rules for how it distributes unemployment, maternity, paternity, family or pre-retirement benefits. But whatever benefits are provided, the questions are relentless. Do we want or do we not want a united Europe? Do we want or do we not want free movement of employees? Do we want or do we not want there to be no discrimination against the Dane or the Greek worker when he changes his place of residence? We support the Balas report, which was also supported by a wide range of Members. This is the only way we can reach a single European insurance system. This is the way to a unified tax system, without differences between us, to build a truly united Europe.

name: Verónica LOPE FONTAGNÉ
text: - Madam President, from the European institutions we have to continue working to facilitate that the free movement of workers in the Union is accompanied by the guarantee of workers' rights. It is a pity that a qualified majority of the Council has not been reached, since the proposal included positive aspects, such as the increase in the export period of unemployment benefits - which would facilitate the search for employment and strengthen the labor mobility of workers. , the improvement of the European coordination of long-term care benefits and the preservation of the principle of equal treatment that avoids the indexation of benefits for dependent children. I would also consider it important that the specificities of highly mobile sectors be respected, which must be taken into account when legislating. And to conclude, as today is my last intervention in this house, I would like to say goodbye, thanking you for these ten years. Much work has been done, with consensus among the different groups, and that has allowed us - and specifically referring to the Employment Committee - to carry out a great deal of work in favor of the most disadvantaged, an effort unknown in many cases by European citizens . And I just hope that this harmony will continue to exist in the next legislature, as it is important if we are to achieve a stronger and more united Union.

name: Michael DETJEN
text: - Madam President, Commissioner! Today we have the opportunity to continue the success story of the Posting of Workers Directive: equal pay for equal work in the same place. The same social rights across Europe would be what we Europeans should be committed to. Guillaume Balas made a good suggestion for this. The European internal market consists not only of the euro and freedom of movement, but also of the social protection of these rights. The rights of the people, as envisaged by Guillaume Balas, are important to people's mobility and we would do well to support people. The horror stories about the export of unemployment benefits and child benefits have no factual basis. The fact is, this is pure nationalist propaganda, because not a thousand will engage in this abuse. Tomorrow I will speak out in favor of the revision of the social security systems. We should leave that to the nationalists to play off east against west, north against south.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: - (NL) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, yesterday we approved the creation of a European Labor Authority and also reviewed the rules on contracts. Earlier we tackled the posting rules, which now enshrines the principle of "equal pay for equal work in the same place". We have previously worked on the social pillar and the balance between work and private life. Europe is finally showing its social face. The coordination of social security systems must become the crowning glory. But what we see is that actually a technical file has quickly become an explosive file in the media. The report determines which country is responsible for the payment of benefits in which case. In many cases, people used to fall between the folds of the social safety net. For example, as a Belgian, you could have given the best of yourself in Germany for twenty years and subsequently found that you could not count on unemployment benefits in Belgium or Germany. That will be a thing of the past. Still, I will abstain tomorrow. I do this because of a specific Belgian situation. I do not agree with the scheme that only up to one month of unemployment benefits would be paid. I agreed more with Commissioner Thyssen's proposal. Because with just one month of work you do not create a link with the labor market. Having said this, in my country it is specifically about 179 people, mainly Dutch and French, in the year 2017. Soon there is talk about welfare tourism. That is a deliberately misrepresentation of the facts. I would also like to say that.

name: Ole CHRISTENSEN
text: - Madam President! I very much agree that we need to have some clear rules that ensure the migrant worker socially. But there is a need for a better balance than that in the Balas report. Rights and duties simply do not go hand in hand, and national citizens are discriminated against in relation to the migrant workforce. The three biggest problems are the following: firstly, the right to unemployment benefits from day one. How much connection do you really have with a country's labor market if you have only been employed there for a short time? I think that the connection to the labor market you came from is greater, therefore a longer earning period, preferably 3 months. Secondly, the right to export unemployment benefits for 6 months. There are varying degrees of labor market policies that are very negatively affected by this. And there is no evidence that an increase in the export of unemployment benefits increases the number of jobs. Therefore, we determine to stick to 3 months export. Thirdly, a system of free choice for frontier workers, I simply do not believe in that. We need clearer rules.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: - (NL) Mr President, more and more Europeans live or work in a country other than where they come from. It is precisely for these people that social security must be properly arranged. People should never be disadvantaged just because they cross a border. This is crucial, especially in a border region like my own Limburg. Still, I will have to vote against this text tomorrow, even though many good things are being arranged. That's because of unemployment benefits. Unemployment benefits are important. People who receive them must be returned to work as soon as possible. That is good for them and for society as a whole. So good for all of us. So there must be enough real incentives to actively look for work. We see that those incentives are simply lacking in the export of unemployment benefits. To give an example: in the Netherlands we export about 4,000 unemployment benefits per year. Of those four thousand, 0.6 percent actually find a new job during the period of export. 0.6 percent: that's an absurdly low figure. This undermines the support for our collective social security and it affects the sense of social justice in our society. Now doubling that period of export without adding any real incentives to actually look for work is not justified in our opinion, and therefore unacceptable for the CDA.

name: Maria ARENA
text: - Madam President, fundamental freedoms, including freedom of movement, are accompanied by rules, which are, in terms of worker mobility, rules of social protection, because Europe is a Europe of social protection, but also rules of non-unfair competition. However, the review of the coordination of social security systems, as proposed in the report by my colleague, Mr Balas, goes in this direction. It is undoubtedly not perfect, but it has the merit of making clear proposals to improve the situation of workers' rights within the Union and to fight against fraud, which is a practiced sport, ladies and gentlemen, no not by the unemployed who would sunbathe on the pill, but by unscrupulous companies recruiting unprotected workers in Europe today. It is therefore against this unfair competition which weakens the social security systems that we must fight and we must therefore support this proposal to confirm a position of the European Parliament which is European, and not support the national, even nationalist positions of certain Member States.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: - This being my last plenary speech, allow me, Madam President, to do it in order to take stock of the mandate's priorities, and this proposal for the coordination of social security systems illustrates well the social priorities we defend for the European Union where, at the top of our priorities, we had the protection of the European social model that distinguishes us from the rest of the world, a model that protects citizens at all stages, guaranteeing greater dignity, greater conditions of social equity, greater conditions of social convergence, in a convergence which is associated with growth, in a Europe that takes advantage of mobility, of its diversity, in order to enhance the capabilities of each citizen. Now, mobility must be associated with greater social responsibility so that we do not fall into situations of taking advantage of workers' fragility. But the Europe that calls for unity in terms of mobility cannot then take refuge in nationalisms, in terms of protecting citizens. We therefore argue that the Member States that use European transnational labor and expertise, assume their social responsibilities towards these workers and their families. We therefore advocate that social benefits be paid at the level of contributions from the Member State where the work was provided. It is therefore necessary to ensure that the worker has the same rights as nationals of the country where he works. Freedom of movement must be linked to equity in protection for a more just, more equitable Europe. Madam President, Dear Colleagues, let me tell you that it was an honor to represent the Portuguese, leaving here the contribution to a more social Europe.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: - Madam President, the greatest benefit of a common Europe is the free movement of people, goods and services. The mobility of people is really considerable and it doesn't matter if it is for work or study. Another phenomenon is the cross-border workforce, so we need to coordinate the social security system for them so that we can remove administrative barriers, language barriers, and provide such migrants with maximum help and protection. I see the coordination of social security systems as a process that we will improve, improve and that will be able to guarantee all workers, regardless of their rights, throughout the European Union. Coordination is also needed because some Member States are already adjusting their own social security conditions for workers and their families, in breach of existing EU rules and being discriminatory in this respect. As a negative example, I will mention Austria and its indexation of family allowances.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, the increase in labour mobility means that the social rights need to be protected better. However, the freedom of movement of workers is currently challenged by a blocking minority in the Council. But colleagues, we are speaking about the things that are most important for the total majority of our workers, their social entitlements. In many cases, allowances determine how the citizens perceive the quality of their citizenship and as a result, how they appreciate the functioning of the EU. It is regretful that the Council does not give that much importance to social benefits. The indexation actively promoted by some countries is the road to the disaggregation of the EU. It puts our social systems in competition and favours the outflow of young workers from the new Member States. It’s true that in the current framework, the Member States are free to decide on the conditions for benefits and insurance, but these decisions must be made in accordance with the principle of equal treatment and non-discrimination.

name: David COBURN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, it’s all very interesting but this is a very dangerous thing for the United Kingdom. Britain’s social security system is based on need, and not on contributions as it is on the continent. In France, for example, you can only draw out what you pay into the system. If you have not paid in, you can’t draw out. This is why migrants queue at Calais to go to the United Kingdom but they are not queuing at Dover to come to Calais. This is because the social security system is more open to people who have just arrived.  There’s nothing wrong in that. Our system is good for the system we’ve got. Your system is good for what you have. But the trouble is, the two systems are utterly incompatible. Any change to that system could bankrupt Britain’s social security system, which is one of the major reasons we voted for Brexit. We are basically concerned that it would bankrupt our social security system and put enormous stress on our health service, which is also free at point of use so people can just turn up and use the system.  This creates problems. It means that we could never have a true integration of these systems. And why should we? Why should we not have competition throughout Europe? Why should we all have some monosyllabic Soviet system which is decided by the European Council or decided by the Commission? That really isn’t going to work.  We need to have competition in wages. We have to have competition in everything. That’s what makes a vibrant economy and why the British economy is booming, despite Brexit, and the European economy is not doing very well at all. The euro looks as if it’s in a very bad state. Even Deutsche Bank is having problems and the Italian banks are all on the rocks. So, all in all, our system does seem to be superior.  Any attempt to try and make all the systems in Europe exactly the same is going to lead to one thing: a form of, I don’t know, Soviet communism, whatever. It’s a very, very bad and dangerous idea and I’m afraid Britain can have nothing to do with it, which is all the more reason for us to leave.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I honestly don't understand the position of some of my colleagues here. It's totally confusing! We do not want a single social security system to be made, but to be respected for the worker who benefits from mobility and goes to a state - to be respected the same security system as for the domestic worker. It is incredible to want a single market, to have the mobility of workers, but not to respect the conditions of security and payment of equal pay. Sure, it may not be the best option, but let's compare - nothing with what this report brings new. It's a compromise, I say. We must stop having cases like Austria, which has diminished and is now in violation. But the Prime Minister of Denmark also informed us that he will want to apply a reduction in allowances or differentiated allowances for the children of workers from other states. Do we want a united Europe? Do we want a single market? This is provided for in the treaty. And then we must respect not only the pay "equal work, equal pay", but we must also respect the security systems.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, we need to make it clear that insurance systems are the responsibility of the Member States. Secondly, the flexibility in work applied in recent years, and in particular the system of seconded officials, a system that creates social dumping, has complicated all issues. No insurance system should be converted into a subsidy system for neighboring countries, as is currently the case with the Greek insurance system for the 200,000 employees in Greece from Bulgaria. Thirdly, no discrimination against those who work legally in the Member States. At the same time, however, not a policy of exporting bonuses. Unemployment benefit supports those who are unemployed in order to find a job. Therefore, it will support them for as long as they remain in that country. The only possibility of export should be the pension, because this is a right that can be carried in one's own country. Therefore, we need to look at all these issues, as well as the brain drain, which has led to a bleed of social security. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: – Madam President, it was not necessarily a blue card, it was more a point of order. Obviously Mr Coburn, or anybody else from the EFDD, didn’t bother enough with this debate to actually show up in time for the start of this debate, and I think it’s a bit unfair that after he’s had his beauty sleep and his breakfast he decides to show up and still has a speaking time afterwards. I don’t understand where this comes from. If you really care about these debates you can show up on time and participate. If you don’t show up, that’s your choice.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I am a very fair chairperson, so I think people who are on a list, if they arrive, I usually allow them speak. But your point is well made and I’m sure Mr Coburn will set his alarm clock earlier for the next early debate that we have.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I am very concerned about this debate. Our continuity and respect for the social rights of male and female workers, to avoid fraud, unfair competition, cases of lack of rights, legal uncertainties, is our obligation. I will give you several examples. Mobility for Galicians is called emigrating: the Galician seamen who quoted in Norway and who continue this same year waiting to collect their social benefits - a greeting to them, Long Hope; Galician and northern Portugal workers who go from one place to another and who often have complex social situations; emigrants returned from other European states, and also from Switzerland, who return to our country and to whom illnesses and social benefits are not recognized. Labor mobility in my country is called emigrating, I insist on that, Commissioner, and that is why I have put forward several parliamentary questions on these three issues, and that is why we must work to have this equal treatment.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: - Madam President, this proposal, which some are trying to block, has a number of advances compared to the Commission's proposal to guarantee the protection of workers' rights. But let us be clear, the coordination of social security systems can only occur if they exist to coordinate, maintaining their public, universal and solidary dimension that ensures a redistributive character and a fair and dignified remuneration after a lifetime of work. This is not the path the European Union wants to take, as was clear two weeks ago, with the approval of a pan-European pension fund that opens the way for the privatization of Social Security, or when it encourages theses of raising the retirement age to guarantee the sustainability of social security systems, an example of which a study recently ordered by employers in Portugal. The recent advances achieved in Portugal, with our proposal and contribution, although insufficient, determine that it is in the creation of jobs and in the valorization of wages that this sustainability of social security systems is guaranteed to which the increase and valorization of rights must be added. labor and social issues.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me thank the honourable Members for this interesting and lively debate on this important matter. We proposed a modernisation of the rules on social security coordination two and half years ago, so well in time, and we launched the proposal because we need to preserve the social protection of the increasing group of mobile citizens.  In the context of increased labour mobility and major demographic changes, the existing rules must be updated to adequately protect citizens’ rights. Free movement of workers only exists if mobile workers preserve their social protection.  The modernisation will provide the national administrations with better tools to fight fraud and abuses. Citizens and employers will greatly benefit from the clear deadlines that we wish to introduce for cooperation between national administrations, national authorities, and I also mentioned the legal certainty that we owe to our citizens, to workers and businesses that exercise their free movement.  These are all reasons why we cannot afford to postpone the modernisation of the coordination of social security rules and the Commission therefore counts on this Parliament to adopt a position in first reading that shows our citizens and workers and businesses alike that we care about social security rights and that we care about a good functioning of our internal market, because indeed coordination of social security systems is crucial for free movement, and free movement of workers, the self-employed and companies is crucial for the internal market. I trust that this Parliament will show citizens, up to the last day of its mandate, that their rights also count. That this Parliament will show Europe’s businesses that it understands their needs, and also the needs of the SMEs, and that it will show to all that Europe can deliver.  And if you will allow me, Madam President, to use one more minute of your time: this is my last intervention in a debate in this Parliament and the cooperation between the Commission and the Members of the Parliament, especially the members of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (EMPL), has always been excellent. I think we were able to realise a lot together and I want to thank you for all the achievements that we were able to make together. I wish you all the best.  (Applause)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Thank you Ms Thyssen. I’m sure the colleagues on the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs know you better, perhaps, but I want to say, on my own behalf, thank you for your cooperation and for always meeting groups and keeping in mind the best interests of our citizens. I wish you well, on behalf of Parliament here this morning, in your endeavours for the future. Thank you so much.

name: Guillaume BALAS
text: protractor. - Madam President, Commissioner, since this is your last intervention, a word to tell you that, if I am a follower of the left-right divide, you have shown me that, sometimes, many people on the right can be more progressive than many on the left. I wanted to thank you for that. You know what Gandhi said: we think the enemy is hate, when in fact it is fear. I heard a lot of fears in the speeches this morning. Lots of fears which lead to say anything, for example by asserting that allowing the export of only six months of unemployment benefits acquired by working 20 years in a country, it would be a gift which some workers in the Eastern Europe would benefit to the detriment of those in the North or the West. We know that a study by the European Parliament has shown that exporting six months of unemployment benefits makes it possible to integrate better into the labor market and to find work more easily than with three months, but we systematically hear the reverse here! MPs from Northern Europe, Western Europe, do not say a word about the big companies which, for their part, organize social dumping - because it is not the workers of the East who organize the social dumping, it is these very large companies - and do not seek at any time to coerce these large companies in order to ensure effective protection for workers. I can see, then, that it is fear that is ruling, the fear of these large multinationals that you do not dare to confront today, and I find that eminently sad. I am particularly sad to hear some people speak first of the workers of their country rather than of all European workers - and say that among these voices, some, fortunately in the minority, say they are leftist! How can we first talk about our country, the interests of our country, because there are European elections, without first looking at all the workers who share common interests in the face of precisely these large companies, which we know are putting workers in competition with each other to weaken our protections for all? So yes, I appeal to all progressives in this Parliament, to all those who believe that Europe can be synonymous with progress, even that Europe only has meaning if it brings progress for all citizens , regardless of their nationality, that it is on this principle that Europe is founded. So yes, I appeal to them, not by saying that this text is perfect, that it solves everything, but that it is a sign today of unity, progress and peaceful relations between employees, to fight against the unfair competition that we are trying to create between them, in short to ensure that at last Europe and progress are two words that rhyme together.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Thank you to our rapporteur. If only we could replace fear with hope. Because I have time and I am in poetic mood, I will repeat again the lines of a very famous Irish poet, Seamus Heaney: ‘So hope for a great sea-change on the far side of revenge. Believe that a further shore is reachable from here. Believe in miracles and cures and healing wellsʼ. The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: in writing. - It is unacceptable that this dossier, after the failure of the Council, is forced by a left-wing majority in the EP without a numerical or conceptual majority. In its current form, the regulation prefers to build walls between Western and Eastern Europe. The draft regulation and the left-wing amendments tabled to it are unacceptable in terms of applicable law, administrative provisions, prior notification of postings and the indexation of family benefits, and even run counter to the EU Treaties. I have said many times before: there can be no secondary children in the EU! Whoever works in a Western European country contributes to that country's social security and tax system with the same contributions as local workers, why would he still receive less benefits just because his child lives in another Member State? This is clear discrimination! Overall, I consider that neither the basic text nor the proposed amendments will reach the level that would allow me to vote in favor of the report. This is particularly true in the light of what the EP has recently adopted on the mobility package. The two are closely related in many respects. That is why I will be voting against this proposal, because it is only for the protectionism of Western European countries and not for the benefit of Europe.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. - As so many times in its history, the Union is at a crossroads. In sixty peaceful years, Europe has been completely transformed. Borders have disappeared, and European citizens can move, work and live freely in any Member State. For a growing number of our companies, the market now means the Union as a whole. Our young people go abroad to study for granted. Europe has become a real, common home from an abstract geographical concept, but citizens want more. The Union will only fulfill its vocation if it hears their voices and meets legitimate expectations. And the expectation is nothing more than a social Europe. A Union that ensures that its citizens not only have declared rights but also the opportunity to exercise those rights. Whoever works should not be miserable. Whoever has worked his life should be safe for his old age. No one should be afraid that an unexpected illness will plague their family. Everyone can expect that if they are in trouble, the social network will protect, live or work in any member state. One of the basic conditions for all this is the coordination of the social and labor systems of the Member States. Europe can only be truly common, it can only be successful if the Union itself is at the heart of the Union. That is why I support the proposal before us, which is why I stand up for a strong, social Europe!

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate with the Prime Minister of the Republic of Latvia, Krišjānis Kariņš, on the Future of Europe (2019/2673(RSP)). Today, it is possible to start immediately. Everybody knows our friend, a former Member of this Parliament for this year, the Prime Minister of Latvia. Thank you, Mr Kariņš, for accepting our invitation for this important debate on the future of the European Union. You are at home today. You know this Parliament very well and the debate with you will be very easy. You know very well the position of the European Parliament, the importance of the European Parliament. You know the President of the European Commission and the Vice-President of the European Commission. Thank you for coming. As you know, we want the European Parliament at the centre of the political debate on the future of the European Union. You are a Member ad honorem of this Parliament, for this, welcome and I immediately give you the floor.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Latvijas premjerministrs. – Augsti godātais Tajāni kungs! Priekšsēdētāj Junkera kungs! Cienījamās deputātes! Godājamie deputāti! Dāmas un kungi! Draugi! Man ir patiesi milzīgs prieks šodien jūs uzrunāt par tik nozīmīgu tēmu — par Eiropas nākotni. Kā jūs zināt, es gandrīz desmit gadus esmu strādājis šajā parlamentā kā parlamentārietis, un es šo to šajā laikā arī varbūt paguvu iemācīties. Die eine Sache, die ich gelernt habe, ist, dass, wenn man hier eine Rede halten möchte, man sich mindestens in drei Sprachen ausdrücken können muss, sonst geht es nicht. Also das ist jetzt die zweite Sprache. Le français est trop difficile pour moi, malheureusement. Je comprends la langue, mais pour un discours, c’est un petit peu trop difficile.  But I’ll continue in English. This is language four. This is a time of change: the end of the term, the coming of the elections. It really is a time for reflection. But, before we look forward, I want to go a little bit back in history to give a little bit of context. Latvia. Europe. What binds Europeans? Really, when you think about it, it is the shared history coming from Ancient Greece and Rome, through Christianity that spread throughout Europe. As Christianity and this culture had spread throughout Europe, the last remaining outpost were the Baltics that still had not become part, shall we say, of this common shared cultural and religious heritage. It was only at the turn of the 12th and 13th century that the Pope in Rome said ‘OK’ to a crusade against the non—Christians in the Baltics. Since that time, our country has gone through all of the cultural developments, changes and upheavals that the rest of Europe went through, whether it is the Renaissance, the Reformation or the Enlightenment. Today, our country is predominantly, at least historically, a Lutheran country with strong Catholicism in the south east. It is very clear that, through our history, we have been part of the northern European cultural area. We view ourselves as being rather pragmatic, very patient, and – we’d like to think – rational and law-abiding as well. In culture there’s a strong creativity and personal enterprise that always presses its way through. For hundreds of years after the introduction of Christianity, our country faced various periods of political and military occupation, coming at times from Germany at times from Poland, at times from Sweden, and at times from Russia. Throughout this time, of course, we maintained our identity and our language and culture. It was not until the end of the First World War in 1918 that we finally declared our own independence. And it took two more years for the War of Independence to free the country of the remaining German and Russian armies which was still there at the time. If you want a personal family history, my father’s father – my grandfather – entered the Tsarist Army as a soldier for the Tsar, then he became a Bolshevik soldier, fighting the Revolution against Tsar, and then, when his unit heard that our country had declared independence, he came home and became a freedom fighter for independence. A typical history at the time. Our country developed between the wars. Then the Second World War came. It did a lot of damage throughout Europe. That’s where I come into the picture. I am the son of refugees, wartime refugees. My parents were children in 1944 – my mother was eight and my father was 14 – and fled in small boats from Latvia to Sweden. About 5 000 Latvians came to Sweden and about 200 000 fled to Germany as the advancing Soviet army was coming a second time, devastating the country. My parents grew up in Sweden, met and married, and then they emigrated further to the US, where I was born, together with my two sisters. I first came to Latvia in 1984. At the time, I was a high school student in the last refugee school, the Latvian Refugee High School, in Münster in Germany. That’s when I first came to Latvia. It was a different world, a different country. Everything was grey, people didn’t smile on the streets, Soviet soldiers on leave, but everywhere, everything was in Russian. You could see a visible lack of investment in any kind of infrastructure, whether they were buildings or roads or bridges. You could see decay. As Solidarity came in the late 1980s in Poland and the Berlin Wall fell at the end of 1989, change happened in our country as well. We finally regained independence in 1991. In a very short amount of time, we developed democratic institutions, we developed free enterprise, we developed a banking system, and we developed a market economy, basically from scratch. In 2004, only 13 years after regaining independence, we joined the EU and NATO. In a couple of weeks’ time, we’re going to celebrate 15 years since we joined the European Union and I can say, on behalf of my country, we have not regretted a single day since we joined the EU. (Applause) So what is the EU? Well, first of all – and it must be stressed – it is a union of values, freedom, democracy and the rule of law. Historically, in Europe, how were disputes settled? With soldiers, with guns, with rifles, with tanks, and with destruction. How do we do it today? Tiresome debate, discussion votes, but it is a heck of a lot better than the way it was done before. The EU is also about economic development, and at the core of that, is the single market. By opening up our borders to one another, we have created one of the largest markets in the world: over 500 million people, in sheer economic size roughly equivalent to the United States, which is considered the world’s strongest economy. But all is really not well in the EU. All of us know, as politicians, that there’s a lot of anti-EU sentiment going around. There are politicians who are offering very simplistic answers to very complex issues. Generally, they are referred to as populists. My simple message is: don’t fight the populists – it is a worthless endeavour – but try to understand why people are listening to the populists, and why people are unhappy. So why are people unhappy? What happened? Go back 10 years to 2008—2009. A bank collapsed in the US. Ok, they collapse every once in a while. That led into a chain reaction of a banking crisis around the world, especially in Europe. That led to an economic crisis, the biggest we had had since the Great Depression. My own country’s GDP fell by almost one quarter, one of the steepest drops in about a year and a half. Other countries fell as well, maybe not so badly. As we were coming out of the economic crisis, what happened a few years ago? The migration crisis. The unrest in the Middle East. It started as peaceful revolutions that turned into bloody revolutions and then refugees, migrants. The result of all of that is what I would call a political crisis, people losing faith in the system. It’s understandable that they have lost faith. We have to help them regain it. If you look at voters, what are their main concerns? I say there are four: jobs, the way of life – translated into immigration – the environment; and safety and security. To talk about the future of Europe, you need to address all these four issues. So what about jobs? The EU has a mechanism to foster job growth and it is that which is simply referred to as the single market. I think of a story I remember as a child – it may have been one of Aesop’s Fables – where a father has three sons. He gives a stick to one of his sons and says, ‘break this stick’ and the son breaks the stick. Then he gives another stick to the son. The son breaks the stick and he says, ‘well, what’s the difficulty?’ Then he gives the son a whole bundle of sticks together. He says, ‘now break the stick’. He tries and tries again, gives it to a brother, can’t. The third brother – can’t. The simple moral of the story is, when you’re alone, you can be broken easily, like a stick, like a twig. When you’re united, you’re powerful, and that is the beauty of the single market. We have challenges to the single market coming from the outside. There is a rising China and there’s a US whose administration seems to be faltering a little bit in its belief that it has a leading role to play in organising world affairs and world trade. Now, what about China? A country that openly subsidises its huge industries. These industries are coming into Europe and competing with an unfair advantage. At the same time, European companies don’t have equal access to Chinese markets. What’s the answer? I say the answer to unfair competition is not protectionism. We cannot go the way of the Chinese. We should not become more like the Chinese, but demand that the Chinese become more like us in terms of opening up their market. We have a lot of clout as a union and as a single market. This is what we need to use, not as individual sticks, but as that bundle that cannot be broken and can change things in the world. Inside the EU we still have hurdles to overcome and this has to do with the internal barriers still to the single market, especially in the digital sphere, as well as is in the services sphere. Ask yourselves: why are the largest internet companies coming from the US? Why aren’t they European? I think the answer is pretty obvious. The US has a dollar zone, it has a federal government and a federal budget, and it has zero barriers between the states in terms of trade. They have a truly united single market, smaller than ours – 330 million. We have a larger one, but we have too many hurdles. So, if we talk of wanting to have national champions, I don’t think that we should bend our competition laws to artificially create national champions. I think we have to tear down the barriers within the single market to let those champions grow themselves and they can take on the world, they can take on the US, and they can easily take on China. (Applause) One of the cornerstones of the single market is the financial system, the banks. Ten years ago, the biggest threat to the banks was liquidity, so we created a banking union to make sure that the ECB is overseeing the largest banks and to make it safer and ensure that the banks will be there tomorrow morning when we wake up. The world has changed since those ten years. Liquidity is not the main problem. A new problem has emerged, which is terrorism in Europe and the financing of terrorism. How does that often happen? Through illicit funds moving through the European banking system. So where are we on anti-money laundering (AML)? In this House, I was the co—rapporteur, with Ms Sargentini, on the last two AML directives. I learned a thing or two about policy. Anti—money laundering legislation is all about risk assessment and reducing the risk of dirty money entering the system. To the east of Europe, we have a country, a big economy, Russia, and, for the past 20 years, money from Russia has been wanting to flee that country. Why? Because Europe is safe. Europe has the rule of law. In Europe no one takes their money away without going through the courts. You can’t do that. That money wants to come to Europe. Some of it is clean, maybe most of it is clean, but some of it is not clean and those who are working with unclean money, the criminals – I’m not talking about people looking to optimise their tax returns and itemising something that may be an expense or not, I’m talking about hardened criminals that are moving millions of euros – are flying like hawks above the ground and they’re looking at the weak links in the chain: in this country, you can do that, in this country, you can do that, in this country, you can do that. Our country was also part of this chain and not alone. Money laundering is a European problem. Since becoming Prime Minister, I don’t have the patience to wait for all of us to get our act together so I’m cleaning up my house. (Applause) We’re going to have the cleanest and the most resilient banking system in Europe. In one and a half years’ time, we’ll gladly consult anyone in this room in and in this House on how to clean up a banking system, but it is a little bit like fighting rats. I can make sure that I get the rats out of my house and my house will be clean, but what about my neighbours? The criminals may have left Latvia for now, but they have unfortunately – I’m convinced – not left Europe. So we have to clean the whole neighbourhood. That means that anti-money laundering supervision has to be centralised, just as prudential supervision, a very strong and important step forward. (Applause) Another concern of voters is immigration, the way of life. There are no simple answers here. I don’t have them. I don’t think anyone does. The truth is that Europe is a fantastic destination to come to live and to work. We have stable economies, we have stable democracies, we have the rule of law, we have individual freedom, and a lot of our neighbours do not. As autocracy grows, the pressure on wanting to come into the EU will only increase. It will not go away. So we have to learn to deal with it. My country has dealt with a little bit of immigration as well. During the 50 years of Soviet occupation, more than 700 000 people – migrants – arrived in our country. That’s one third of the population. We’re only two million and 700 000 came in. Our government had no say over this because we had no government. It was Moscow making the decisions: fully making the decisions, no co—decision, no say. After regaining independence, how have we dealt with it? With the one big ‘I’ word: integration. You have to work with the people, you have to work on your educational system, bring the people into our culture, bring the immigrants into your cultures. This is the way forward. We cannot fight that. You cannot stop people wanting to come into Europe. We are a preferred destination, but we have to work on integrating these people. But we can do something to mitigate the flows and the obvious answer to that is the outer border, Frontex. This is a wonderful programme that needs to be strengthened. (Applause) Because, if we can show our voters that we control the outer border, then we can have free inner borders and we won’t have the situation of a few years ago where, within the Schengen zone, we remember going between Strasbourg and Germany – those of us who stayed in hotels there – that the bridge was sometimes closed or they were checking every car. This is not the way forward. We need open internal borders for a single market to work, which means we need firm borders on the outside. We will have to fund refugee camps, it is inevitable. We will have to fund development of economies and the rule of law in third countries. This is inevitable. And we have to work on integration. Europe is still a Union of 28 sovereign countries with their own national identities.
